comments: The class was a first-year seminar, but it was more of a combination of lectures and presentations or discussions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned a lot about a variety of subjects current in the STEM industry right now, and did three week modules on each topic. I improved my critical analysis skills and learned how to properly read and summarize the findings of a journal article.
This was a good class, especially for me as a non-STEM major, to just learn a little bit about a few different science topics that are particularly interesting today.
I developed a stronger understanding of the science world, whether it be exoplanets or viruses.
Learned about some interesting, timely topics in science
I did not take many science classes in high school, so this course exposed me to many topics in science that I had not previously investigated at all.

I acquired a broad overview of several current topics of interest in science. I learned about commonly-used methods for detecting exoplanets, renewable energy technologies and their advantages/disadvantages, GMO crops, and anti-malarial drugs. By working through the assignments, I also acquired greater fluency in reading scientific papers. Finally, the class projects allowed me to practice my presentational skills.
I developed some practical writing and presenting skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course had a very good idea, but it was not executed to its fullest potential. For example, I was very interested in the topic about genetically modified organisms, but found that module to be a little bit boring and not engaging. I think that if each professor was given an outline or a more concrete path to follow, the course could be made better.

I like that the course changes modules every three weeks, so that we get to learn and discuss a few different topics. Additionally, it's cool that each module is taught by a different professor or expert. However, we don't learn anything very in-depth due to the short modules. Also, the class organization was sometimes suspect.
The course presents some extremely interesting information but can feel a bit repetitive after awhile because the class is longer than most.
Deliverables / assignments often fell disconnected from lectures
The structure of this course was definitely the biggest strength because it offered significant amounts of varied, helpful information in a balanced timeframe throughout the semester.

I appreciated the variety of topics that were covered in the class. The two days we spent on each topic was just enough to gather meaningful insight without going too far into the specifics of a particular field. Most topics were presented in a way that made them legible to a person without too much prior knowledge of chemistry, biology, or physics. The only minor exception to this was the seminar on GMO foods, which was more biology-intensive than the rest. One other improvement I would suggest would be more frequent feedback on assignments, as this would help me identify areas in which I need to improve. On the whole, though, I really enjoyed this course.

The course was extremely disorganized. This may be a one-off occurrence, but for the first few lectures, the professor wasn't available and the class wasn't held. Later on, our assignment groups were often left up to us to organize, without any pre-established method of communicating. While the professors and lecturers were often responsive to emails, emailing was often a necessity as details were often left out in our assignments. As of writing this evaluation, we still do not have any grades from the semester. The course is year long, which may be the reason for the lack of grades, but it is still quite frustrating and inconvenient.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was great at getting the other students to interact with each other and further each other's knowledge through group projects, problem sets, and group discussions.
N/a
Because the classes were online, we were able to get lectures from people in different regions. This offered insight with mich not have been reasonably attained if the class was run in person.

The frequent group projects helped build a sense of community in the class. By meeting with group members to discuss project ideas, I had a chance to get to know them a little better than I could by merely seeing them in class. The assignments were also well-geared towards a virtual learning environment. I appreciate that the quizzes/tests were replaced by PSETS and presentations, as the latter are not significantly altered by the need to work online. On occasion, the video connection would freeze, making it hard to understand the lecturer. This, however, did not happen too often and so did not pose a great problem.
The seminar was held virtually, but it felt quite similar to what an in-person seminar would be like (at least I would assume).

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to a student looking to get a broad overview of many topics in science and technology. However, for students who prefer a more in depth look a topic, I would not recommend this course to them.

I would recommend it to anybody who is interested in scratching the surface, but not learning very in-depth, about a few areas of science that are interesting at the present time (like energy conservation, exoplanets, infectious diseases, and GMOs). Also, anyone who wants a relatively easy science credit or a fifth class that isn't too time consuming would be well served to take this class. Also, it's a first-year seminar, so you'll get to meet other first-years by taking this course.

This is a great course to ease oneself into STEM without being interested in pursuing a STEM field; in other words, it's a fabulous way to learn more about the world around us without the pressure of memorizing key terms or preparing for stressful tests.
Yes, if a student is looking for a Science credit

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because it was very interesting and helpful to learn about a wide variety of topics in science. The class was engaging in every cycle, and we also had various types of assignments.

I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn about interesting developments across a broad range of scientific fields. The lectures don't assume prior knowledge of any scientific discipline. The modules covered in the course are thus accessible to anybody who is even remotely interested in science, regardless of their skill level.

It depends on if you are interested in the course content. Email the professor who organizes the course and see if you can get a list of the topics to be covered. If you are interested and can deal with the lack of organization, the course isn't difficult and I would recommend it.
